name: Reagan's Pagans, Ron's Prawns Quiz | Word Play | 25 Questions

questions.text:
Please note: This quiz was written several years ago when punctuation was allowed in Fill in the Blank quizzes. This means you WILL need to include apostrophes in the answer if appropriate.

Taylor's manufacturing plants (not a perfect rhyme)
questions.explanation:
Zachary's factories.

	"Old Rough and Ready"

Dwight's tights.

	His campaign slogan was "I like Ike."

Jackson's klaxons & Jackson's claxons.

	"Old Hickory"

Johnson's Swansons.

	LBJ

Hayes's mazes & Hayes' mazes.

	"Dark-Horse President." Did you know that the B. stands for Birchard?

Kennedy's remedies.

	Jack and JFK. Some people refer to his administration as Camelot.

Chester's jesters.

	"Elegant Arthur" or "The Gentleman Boss."

Theodore's minotaurs.

	Teddy and "Trust Buster." He believed in "speaking softly and carrying a big stick."

Nixon's vixens.

	"Tricky Dick"

Martin's cartons.

	"Old Kinderhook." Some people think the expression "OK" comes from this nickname. He was born and died in Kinderhook, New York.

questions.text: Lincoln's sexy girlfriends (not that Mary would have stood for any of THAT!)
questions.explanation:
Abe's babes.

	"Honest Abe" and "The Illinois Rail-Splitter"

questions.text: If clumsy Clinton carries a full cup of coffee around, this is the result.
questions.explanation:
Bill's spills.

	Bill. He probably has ruder nicknames, but I won't reproduce them here.

questions.correct: Ulysses's sissies & Ulysses' sissies & Ulysses' sisses & Ulysses's sisses
questions.explanation:
Ulysses's sissies & Ulysses' sissies & Ulysses' sisses & Ulysses's sisses.

	"Hero of Appomattox"

Harry's dairies.

	"Give 'Em Hell Harry"

Calvin's albums.

	"Silent Cal"

Thomas's promises & Thomas' promises.

	"The Sage of Monticello"

George's forges.

	"Dub-ya"

John's lawns.

	"Atlas of Independence"

Carter's martyrs.

	Jimmy--what a nice man he is. A Nobel Peace Prize winner.

Madison's Radissons.

	Husband of Dolly.

questions.text: James Knox's sodas (may not be a perfect rhyme depending on how you pronounce his last name)
questions.explanation:
Polk's cokes.

	"Young Hickory"

Harrison's garrisons.

	"Old Tippecanoe"

Gerald's heralds.

	Jerry--the poor guy was always being caught on camera while tripping or stumbling.

questions.correct: Jimmy's gimmes & Jimmys gimmes&jimmys gimmies&jimmy's gimmies
questions.explanation:
Jimmy's gimmes & Jimmys gimmes&jimmys gimmies&jimmy's gimmies.

	Jimmy, we need you now, more than ever.

Grant's pants & Grants pants.

	"U.S. (as in United States) Grant"
